name: Hololens2
description: Microsoft HoloLens 2 is a pair of untethered mixed reality smart glasses with powerful computing capability. Wearing the headset, you are able to use hands and fingers to interact with virtual objects or speak to give your commands. The headset can scan and understand your environment and objects within so that virtual objects can be interacted with the real world objects. Spatial remote collaboration allows you to meet up with people’s digital avatars and collaboration in real time. Currently, hololens 2 is mainly targeted to enterprises for training purposes and is hard to get.
use_cases: Remote Assist, Industrial Medical and Educational Training, Games & Entertainment
related_softwares: Dynamics 365 Remote Assist, Azure Spatial Anchors, Remote Rendering, Azure Digital Twins, Unity, PiXYZ, Microsoft Edge
compatibility: Cross-platform support: Deliver the value of mixed reality across mobile devices, headsets, PCs, and augmented reality (AR) platforms. Azure Kinect DK supports Windows and Linux (preview), and mixed reality services on Azure support development for HoloLens, iOS, and Android.
possible_interactions: Hand tracking, Eye tracking, Voice recognition, Windows Hello, Spatial Mapping(means Real-time environment mesh), Mixed Reality Capture(means Mixed hologram and physical environment photos and videos)
limitations:
FoV still is not big enough
Hand tracking has to be in view

name: MagicLeap1
description: Magic leap 1 is a mixed reality headset. The pair of glasses runs on a computing unit tethered to it. The glasses can track the physical environment so virtual objects can interact with the physical world. Users can use a controller or limited hand motions to control. Currently, magic leap has many great home & entertainment applications. The company is also willing to collaborate with enterprises.
compatibility: Magic Leap Toolkit (MLTK) provides developers with a set of useful tools that solve specific real-world problems and extend functionality when developing Magic Leap apps in Unity® Software and Unreal Engine.
possible_interactions: eye tracking, hand tracking 8 gestures, spatial tracking, 6dof controller
limitations: tethered power unit, limited hand motions, limited field of view
notes: slightly worse world tracking than hololens, behind in terms of content compared to hololens 2

name: NrealLight
description: Nreal Light is a pair of lightweight mix reality glasses. The glasses mainly target to consumers and developers. It runs on a tethered computing unit or Android phones, which serve as controllers. Popular use cases include shopping, games and entertainment.
use_cases: Everyday use and wear, Games & Entertainment
compatibility: The glass is able to run on a variety of andriod phones.
notes: Users could add on lenses to fit to one’s eyesight; The glass is lightweight and quite fashionable.

name: Epson_Moverio_BT300
description: Experience a new way of seeing the world with the revolutionary Moverio BT-300 smart glasses from Epson®. These highly transparent glasses redefine augmented reality (AR) with a groundbreaking Si-OLED display. Superior transparency, plus a high-resolution camera, ensures seamless integration of digital content with the outside world. Ultra light and comfortable to wear, even over prescription glasses, the BT-300 features a binocular display, making it ideal for side-by-side 3D content. With wireless and Bluetooth® Smart (BLE) connectivity, it supports a wide range of accessories. Powered by an Intel® Atom chipset, running Moverio OS, the BT-300 is the ideal platform for developing AR apps.
use_cases: Education, fitness training, sports, drone, watch videos
compatibility: “Dual-band wireless connectivity and Bluetooth Smart (BLE) enable integration with a wide range of accessories”
notes: DJI Drones: See camera view from the drones, overall flight status, flight mode, compass, batteries, number of satellites. This information is usually shown on phones when using phones to operate. Now on glasses; The glass is very narrow so the users’ peripheral vision is very open; Clear lenses with polar filter addons; Able to be worn with glasses on.

name: ThirdEye_Gen_X2
description: Lightweight mixed reality glasses. At 9.8 ounces, the X2 Mixed Reality Glasses fit a wide field of view, contain powerful sensors, and come with the VisionEye SLAM SDK into an exceptionally minimalistic form factor.
use_cases: Remote Assist, Game & Entertainment, Industrial, Medical and Educational Training, Architecture

name: Vuzix_M400
description: The Vuzix M400 is a pair of professional augmented reality smart glasses made by Vuzix, a manufacturer based in the US. With this glasses on, warehousing employees can scan items by looking at them. Engineers can pull up instructions or call colleagues to get helps.
possible_interactions: multi finger tracking, 3dof, motion tracking, touchpad

name: Vuzix_Blade
description: Blade is a glasses version of smart phones. Paired with phones, users are able to see all the notification sent to phones. Waveguide optics project a see-through image to the user. These advanced optics do not obstruct regular vision and allow the user to perfectly switch between the digital world and reality.
use_cases: Smart phones displays, daily wear and use
related_softwares: Vuzix app on phones, Amazon Alexa, Google assistance
limitations: unable to interact with the virtual contents

name: Optinvent_ORA-2
description: The ORA-2 is a true “wearable tablet” which allows a multitude of applications. It is Comfortable, ergonomic and mobile: The ORA-2 enables hands free mobile computing and AR applications such as remote maintenance, logistics, remote training, situation awareness, and much more. It can run applications as a standalone wearable computer and can connect to the network via WiFi and to any smart device via Bluetooth.
use_cases: Smart phones displays, daily wear and use
notes: can be worn over eye glasses

name: Dreamworld_DreamGlass
description: DreamGlass Air is a lightweight personal cinema that plays on its 100” AR screen anything from your smartphone/tablet (Android,iPhone,iPad), game consoles (PS4, Xbox, Nintendo Switch), PC&Mac, and other electronic devices. It frees up your hands and shows everything in private, delivering the most comfortable viewing experience.
compatibility: Unity, Android, PC Samsung: S8, S8 plus, Note 8, S9, S9 plus,Note 9,S10, S10 plus Huawei: Mate 10, Mate 10 Pro, P20, P20 pro, Mate 20, Mate 20 Pro,P30, P30 Pro

name: Project_North_Star
description: Project North Star is a affordable Modular AR headset with opensource code. One can buy the full kit or 3D print parts and assesmble.
how_to_buy: opensource, build your own or buy fully assembled https://www.smart-prototyping.com/Project-North-Star-Kit
use_cases: anything that you want to develop
notes: I think this would be good to check out

name: Rokid_Project_Aurora
description: Rokid Project Aurora is a wearable Mixed Reality (MR) accessory for mobile devices. As a combination of Rokid’s state-of-the-art binocular optics, AR and AI capabilities, Rokid Vision extends existing user interfaces (including phones, laptops, gaming consoles, and tables), to greatly improve productivity, entertainment, and gaming experience.
use_cases: Daily wear and use, game & entertainment, remote assistance
notes: capable of face recognition and object recognition using SLAM Corrective lenses available

name: Tesseract_Holoboard_Premium_Edition
description: The Tesseract Holoboard Premium Edition is an augmented reality headset for smartphones by Tesseract, a manufacturer based in India. This device is compatible with smartphones running Android 6.0 and above with OTG (on-the-go) support. Smartphones must also feature a Snapdragon 805 processor or above in order for this device to operate. The Holoboard Premium Edition uses IMU (inertial measurement unit) based tracking as well as proprietary marker-based tracking that makes use of the phone’s front camera. This allows users to interact and place 3D content within the area directly around them.
related_hardwares: enterprise edition(same as premium but doesn’t have hand tracking module), basic edition (no hand tracking, 3dof controller, compatible with iOS)

name: Aryzon_AR_Headset
description: affordable cardboard AR headset using smartphone

name: Mira_Prism
description: The Mira Prism is an augmented reality headset for smartphones made by Mira, a company based in Los Angeles, US. This smartphone AR headset boasts a lightweight design, therefore offering users a comfortable experience. The headset displays AR content by directly reflecting the smartphone’s screen onto a clear lens, hence making it easy for the user to see the content. Users praise the quality of the holograms and also appreciate the affordable price of this 60° FOV augmented reality headset. The AR headset comes with spare replacement lenses.

name: Realmax_Qian
description: The RealMax Qian is a standalone AR headset with a wide FOV made by RealMax, a tech startup based in China. According to RealMax, this wireless augmented reality head-mounted display (HMD) can also alter between VR and AR modes. Furthermore, the Qian features inside-out tracking. The AR headset is packed with power, featuring 4GB RAM, a Qualcomm 835 chip, and 64 GB Flash. The Qian headset features some great specs such as 6DoF tracking, a 100.8-degree FOV and 720p resolution. However, no hand tracking is available although an add-on gesture sensor (such as Leap Motion) could be added to allow for this.

name: Antvr_Mix
description: AR/VR hybrid The ANTVR MIX is a tethered AR headset made by ANTVR, a manufacturer based in Beijing, China. Contrary to most other augmented reality glasses on the market, the MIX requires a constant cable connection to a PC. These AR glasses are small and lightweight (130g) while providing a relatively large FOV of 96° thanks to ANTVR’s proprietary, dual-channel mixed optics. It ships with 3DoF controllers but 6DoF may be available in the future. Content-wise, the MIX is compatible with SteamVR and its large variety of VR applications. This means that users can play VR games (ones that have a dark background) in AR. Outside-in or inside-out tracking Front camera, built in microphone
compatibility: Leap Motion, HTC Vive tracking systems

name: Shadow_Creator_Action_One
description: The Shadow Creator Action One are augmented reality glasses by Shadow Creator, a manufacturer based in China. Users can use gesture control or a remote control to interact with augmented reality content, thus allowing for easy AR interaction. The FOV of the Action One is 45°. Inside out tracking

name: Google_Glass_Enterprise_Edition_2
description: “Glass Enterprise Edition 2 is a wearable device that helps businesses improve the quality of their output, and help their employees work smarter, faster and safer. It provides hands-on workers and professionals with glanceable, voice-activated assistance that is designed to be worn all day with its comfortable, lightweight profile.”
related_softwares: Voice Commands, runs on Android Open Source Platform
possible_interactions: Voice commands, Multi-touch gesture touchpad, Power-saving features On head detection sensor, and Eye-on screen sensor
limitations: no hand tracking and not designed to be immersive

name: Everysight_Raptor
description: Sport Heads-up display Glass itself can have professional wind protection 8 hours battery life Main features shown: HRM(Heart Rate), Controller, Speed, Cadence, Power. Dust and water resistant Raptor’s heads-up route display provides real-time navigation guidance for road and MTB riders, with free maps available worldwide. No stops. No wrong turns. No added charges. Just ride. Raptor connects to your smartphone via Bluetooth so you’re always on top of emails, texts, schedules, and more. Built-in microphone and speaker.
compatibility: iOS, Android Directly links up with phones, sensors and peripherals via ANT+ / Bluetooth Smart technology. Built-in Wi-fi, so one can easily syn workouts, routes, pics, videos, and more via the Everysight app.
possible_interactions: touchpad or bluetooth controller Raptor is controlled via an integrated touchpad in the frames, supporting familiar swipe and tap gestures, even when one is wearing gloves. Voice control is also available for key actions like recording a video, taking a pic, and adjusting volume/ brightness.

name: Toshiba_DynaEdge_AR100
description: DynaEdge™ AR Smart Glasses is a wearable, hands-free Augmented Reality solution designed to help large enterprises improve efficiency, quality and operating flexibility. Backed by decades of mobile computing design expertise, our AR offering delivers a complete solution, incorporating both hardware and software in one turnkey package.
use_cases: The dynaEdge™ AR Smart Glasses enable multiple usage scenarios, including See-What-I-See, Remote Expert, Document Retrieval, Workflow Instructions and Real-Time Data Capture, making it the enterprise solution for tomorrow—starting today.
compatibility: “Armed with the latest Wi-Fi®, Bluetooth® and GPS technologies, the dynaEdge™ AR Smart Glasses can connect to the corporate network, send and receive data, stream live video and track assets.”
possible_interactions: A touchpad and programmable buttons on the HMD and directional buttons on the waist-mounted processor. Advanced software options enable voice and gesture capabilities.
notes: The company said the glass is Untethered, but there is a computing unit. Equipped with a high-resolution camera, the dynaEdge™ AR Smart Glasses can record and live stream video, take photos and scan barcodes.

name: Varjo_XR1
description: XR-1 Developer Edition is a professional mixed reality device for engineers, researchers and designers who are pioneering a new reality. With photorealistic visual fidelity, ultra-low latency and integrated eye tracking, the XR-1 seamlessly merges virtual content with the real world for the first time ever.
notes: VR+AR, can also be worn by people who wear glasses

name: Lightform
description: Structured light scanning on most non reflective surfaces. and project. LFC kit: Attachable camera system for existing projector LF2: full-fledged AR projector
use_cases: Creating a projected AR experience, Creating interactive AR experience based on OSC commands from any device
related_hardwares: Laptop for creation, mobile for controls, projectors for projection
possible_interactions: Not much. Controls for animation playback (no gesture support of any kind)
limitations: No multi-projector support, No real-time scanning-projection, No gesture, LF2 has a minimum focus distance of 3ft, throw ratio of 1.2. It can scan up to 6 ft wide in normal lighting, 12ft wide in a dark room. Scanning glass, mirrors, and highly reflective objects will result in scan holes. Scanning process takes 60-90 seconds, so real-time tracking is not possible.

name: Bose_Frames_Alto_Rondo
description: A first-of-its-kind audio augmented reality platform, which combines the power of wearable audio products, mobile devices and integrated apps.
compatibility: iOS devices only (Android under dev, which no news)
dimension: 51 mm – 16 mm – 155 mm (Lens width – Distance between lenses – Temple length)
limitations: Not really for use indoors since they are sunglasses, only sound

name: Zungle_Viper
description: Bone-induction audio sunglasses
use_cases: Daily wearable, Running, hiking, biking Hearing navigation, Calls, talking to assistants
possible_interactions: All interactions through mobile (purely for music)
notes: Reviews suggest that sound quality can be much better especially when there’s wind

name: Vue_Glasses
description: Everyday smart audio glasses
possible_interactions: You can set gestures on the glasses that allow you to do a range of things like pick up/hang up phone calls, change songs, turn up volume, etc.

name: Echo_Frames
description: The Echo Frames are an interesting low-cost take on the smart spectacles, which save cost by focusing on audio only. Meet Echo Frames - All-day glasses with hands-free access to Alexa.
possible_interactions: Single button control Able to use Google Assistant through selected devices
limitations: Echo Frames are not currently compatible with iOS smartphones. And limited/selected Android devices

name: Tactsuit
description: Tactsuit creates a new way to experience virtual reality, a physical interface between the virtual world and a user’s skin.
price: Tactot (Body piece): $500; Tactosy for Arms (both arms): $250; Tactosy for Hands (both hands): $250; Tactosy for Feet (both feet): $250
how_to_buy: online, only TACTOT (Haptic Vest) is available to B2C (Consumer) clients. Other haptic devices are supposed to be used only for B2B (Enterprise) clients.
use_cases: Gaming, Training, LBVR, Home Entertainment (theater, Concerts, movies)
compatibility: compatible with the HP Omen PC, Zotac and other wearable PCs
possible_interactions: Suit, so pretty much everything that is in contact with the sensors will be tracked

name: Vest_Pro_Strap
description: Meet Vest Pro. Woojer’s bone-shaking, location-specific haptic vest. Vest Pro delivers sensations, so powerful & so accurate, it’ll raise everything from your pulse, right through to the tiny little hairs on the back of your neck…
use_cases: Gaming, Home Theater (Movies, music), Helping hearing-impaired people feel music/vibration, training
compatibility: Optional PC Rig, App through Android & iOS
